page.title: 01North Blyth,Northumberland
page.content: The area of survey is almost entirely sea. The name Cambois implies the curve or crook of the of the bay. The rocks provide extra protection against the sea at the Alcan unloading terminal. Beyond ae fine stetches of sand on both sides of the Wansbeck. These provide a recreational area with haunts for fishers, painters and bird watchers. There is fishing for small bots.Beachcombers collect timber and sea coral There is some discharge from Cambois Power Station and locl sewerage pipes. Large ships from Alcan have to life off the bay, waiting for high tide and several tugs. Sailing ships move across the bay from both Blyth and Newbiggin. Many seabirds await the changes of tide as do the fishermen, who dig for bait when the tide is out and fish when the waves return.
